articles.headline: The End of an Era, for Court and Nation
articles.snippet: Justice Stevens may be the last justice deemed qualified for his independence rather than perceived ideology.
articles.abstract: Justice Stevens may be the last justice deemed qualified for his independence rather than perceived ideology.
articles.lead_paragraph: WASHINGTON — Justice John Paul Stevens, who announced his resignation from the Supreme Court on Friday after 34 years, may be the last justice from a time when ability and independence, rather than perceived ideology, were viewed as the crucial qualifications for a seat on the court. He was nominated in 1975 by President Gerald R. Ford, who said all he wanted was “the finest legal mind I could find.”

articles.headline: U.S. Now Trying Softer Approach Toward Karzai
articles.snippet: Obama administration officials admit privately that the president’s tough-love approach may have been a mistake.
articles.abstract: Obama administration officials admit privately that the president’s tough-love approach may have been a mistake.
articles.lead_paragraph: WASHINGTON — After more than a year of watching America’s ability to influence President Hamid Karzai ebb, Obama administration officials now admit privately that the tough-love approach Mr. Obama adopted when he came to power may have been a big mistake.
articles.byline: By Helene Cooper and Mark Landler

articles.headline: Working Financial Literacy in With the Three R’s
articles.snippet: While more states are beginning to require personal finance instruction, there aren’t enough that do, experts say, and the quality is inconsistent.
articles.abstract: While more states are beginning to require personal finance instruction, there aren’t enough that do, experts say, and the quality is inconsistent.
articles.lead_paragraph: Most Americans aren’t fluent in the language of money. Yet we’re expected to make big financial decisions as early as our teens — Should I take on thousands of dollars of student debt? Should I buy a car? — even though most of us received no formal instruction on financial matters until it was too late.

articles.headline: Many Filers Confused by Stimulus Tax Credit
articles.snippet: Millions of taxpayers did not realize that to have the credit deducted from the total amount of taxes owed, they are required to complete a new form, Schedule M.
articles.abstract: Millions of taxpayers did not realize that to have the credit deducted from the total amount of taxes owed, they are required to complete a new form, Schedule M.
articles.lead_paragraph: As the deadline approaches for filing tax returns, the process of claiming a tax break created by the stimulus package has proved to be more work than millions of people had bargained for.

articles.headline: Pope Put Off Punishing Abusive Priest
articles.snippet: Cardinal Joseph Ratzinger, then a Vatican official, signed a letter in 1985 resisting defrocking a priest who abused children, according to church documents.
articles.abstract: Cardinal Joseph Ratzinger, then a Vatican official, signed a letter in 1985 resisting defrocking a priest who abused children, according to church documents.
articles.lead_paragraph: The priest, convicted of tying up and abusing two young boys in a California church rectory, wanted to leave the ministry.
articles.byline: By Laurie Goodstein and Michael Luo

articles.headline: The Well-Off Are Spending Again — but Carefully
articles.snippet: As the wealthy slowly resume buying, business creeps back for yacht rental companies, jet brokers, jewelry stores and other purveyors of luxury goods.
articles.abstract: As the wealthy slowly resume buying, business creeps back for yacht rental companies, jet brokers, jewelry stores and other purveyors of luxury goods.
articles.lead_paragraph: The wealthy are cautiously opening their wallets again.

articles.headline: As a Hiring Filter, Credit Checks Draw Questions
articles.snippet: Opponents said there was no evidence that people with weak credit are more likely to be bad employees.
articles.abstract: Opponents said there was no evidence that people with weak credit are more likely to be bad employees.
articles.lead_paragraph: In defending employers’ use of credit checks as part of the hiring process, Eric Rosenberg of the TransUnion credit bureau paints a sobering picture.

articles.headline: Polish President Dies in Jet Crash in Russia
articles.snippet: The crash that killed the Polish president happened just as Russia and Poland were beginning to come to terms with the massacre of Polish officers in the same place 70 years ago.
articles.abstract: The crash that killed the Polish president happened just as Russia and Poland were beginning to come to terms with the massacre of Polish officers in the same place 70 years ago.
articles.lead_paragraph: This article was reported by Nicholas Kulish, Ellen Barry and Michal Piotrowski, and written by Ms. Barry.
articles.byline: By Nicholas Kulish, Ellen Barry and Michal Piotrowski

articles.headline: In Mine Safety, a Meek Watchdog
articles.snippet: The Mine Safety and Health Administration remains weak in several areas, and does not always use its powers.
articles.abstract: The Mine Safety and Health Administration remains weak in several areas, and does not always use its powers.
articles.lead_paragraph: This article was reported by Michael Cooper, Gardiner Harris and Eric Lipton, and written by Mr. Cooper.
articles.byline: By Michael Cooper, Gardiner Harris and Eric Lipton

articles.headline: G.O.P. Weighs Political Price of Court Fight
articles.snippet: The retirement of Justice John Paul Stevens presents a test for Republicans as they weigh the risks of waging an ideological battle before midterm elections.
articles.abstract: The retirement of Justice John Paul Stevens presents a test for Republicans as they weigh the risks of waging an ideological battle before midterm elections.
articles.lead_paragraph: WASHINGTON — The retirement of Justice John Paul Stevens presents a test for Republicans as much as it does for President Obama as they weigh how much they want to wage a high-profile battle over ideological issues in the months before crucial midterm elections.
articles.byline: By Peter Baker and Carl Hulse

articles.headline: Tribes of Amazon Find an Ally Out of ‘Avatar’
articles.snippet: The director James Cameron opposes a dam that environmentalists say would devastate the indigenous communities that live along the Xingu River.
articles.abstract: The director James Cameron opposes a dam that environmentalists say would devastate the indigenous communities that live along the Xingu River.
articles.lead_paragraph: VOLTA GRANDE DO XINGU, Brazil — They came from the far reaches of the Amazon, traveling in small boats and canoes for up to three days to discuss their fate. James Cameron, the Hollywood titan, stood before them with orange warrior streaks painted on his face, comparing the threats on their lands to a snake eating its prey.

articles.headline: Is Disney’s Chief Having a Cinderella Moment?
articles.snippet: Robert Iger has not turned out to be the stuffed suit that some feared at Disney. Instead, he is dragging his media conglomerate into a new era.
articles.abstract: Robert Iger has not turned out to be the stuffed suit that some feared at Disney. Instead, he is dragging his media conglomerate into a new era.
articles.lead_paragraph: LOS ANGELES

articles.headline: Innovation, by Order of the Kremlin
articles.snippet: The Russian government is building the first new scientific city since the collapse of the Soviet Union — and it is to be modeled on Silicon Valley.
articles.abstract: The Russian government is building the first new scientific city since the collapse of the Soviet Union — and it is to be modeled on Silicon Valley.
articles.lead_paragraph: MOSCOW

articles.headline: Rethinking a Gospel of the Web
articles.snippet: Who says a closed platform can’t nurture creativity? Apple’s App Store can advance the ideals of innovation — and online democracy, too, Steven Johnson says.
articles.abstract: Who says a closed platform can’t nurture creativity? Apple’s App Store can advance the ideals of innovation — and online democracy, too, Steven Johnson says.
articles.lead_paragraph: FOR about a decade now, ever since it became clear that the jungle of the World Wide Web would triumph over the walled gardens of CompuServe, AOL and MSN, a general consensus has solidified among the otherwise fractious population of People Who Think Big Thoughts About the Internet.

articles.headline: Interest Rates Have Nowhere to Go but Up
articles.snippet: Even as prospects for the American economy brighten, consumers are about to face a sustained period of rising interest rates, economists say.
articles.abstract: Even as prospects for the American economy brighten, consumers are about to face a sustained period of rising interest rates, economists say.
articles.lead_paragraph: Even as prospects for the American economy brighten, consumers are about to face a new financial burden: a sustained period of rising interest rates.

articles.headline: Defending the Papers He Fought
articles.snippet: Brian Tierney, a former public relations executive, is the last man standing in a fight to keep Philadelphia’s newspapers out of the hands of lenders.
articles.abstract: Brian Tierney, a former public relations executive, is the last man standing in a fight to keep Philadelphia’s newspapers out of the hands of lenders.
articles.lead_paragraph: This is the kind of shape the newspaper business is in: Brian Tierney, a former public relations executive with a reputation for going after reporters, has become the last man standing in a fight to keep Philadelphia’s newspapers out of the hands of lenders.

articles.headline: Tensions Rise for Twitter and App Developers
articles.snippet: Developers fear that Twitter could transform from generous benefactor to arch competitor to their start-ups.
articles.abstract: Developers fear that Twitter could transform from generous benefactor to arch competitor to their start-ups.
articles.lead_paragraph: SAN FRANCISCO — It was the beginning of a beautiful relationship.

articles.headline: Viewer Age Rises With Leno Return
articles.snippet: Jay Leno’s audience is up more than 50 percent from Conan O’Brien’s, but the median age for “Tonight Show” viewers has jumped to 56 years.
articles.abstract: Jay Leno’s audience is up more than 50 percent from Conan O’Brien’s, but the median age for “Tonight Show” viewers has jumped to 56 years.
articles.lead_paragraph: EUGENE, Ore. — As Conan O’Brien starts his post-NBC career on a stage here Monday night with the kickoff of his Legally Prohibited From Being Funny on Television Tour, his former employer, NBC, finds itself reliving the good old days, with Jay Leno back where he used to be — hosting “The Tonight Show” and at the top of the late-night ratings.

articles.headline: Recession Arbiters, Wary of Certifying an Upturn
articles.snippet: A committee that determines official turning points plans to announce that it cannot declare an end to the recession.
articles.abstract: A committee that determines official turning points plans to announce that it cannot declare an end to the recession.
articles.lead_paragraph: For the record, this recession isn’t over yet.
articles.byline: By Sewell Chan and Louise Story

articles.headline: Toyota Delayed a U.S. Recall, Documents Show
articles.snippet: Toyota promised a remedy for floor mat problems but did not implement one quickly, raising questions about why federal officials did not force the issue.
articles.abstract: Toyota promised a remedy for floor mat problems but did not implement one quickly, raising questions about why federal officials did not force the issue.
articles.lead_paragraph: DETROIT — The sense of frustration — and urgency — in the e-mail message was palpable.

articles.headline: Europe Unifies to Assist Greece With Line of Aid
articles.snippet: European leaders provided a long-awaited financial rescue line, offering the country up to $40 billion  to meet its debt obligations.
articles.abstract: European leaders provided a long-awaited financial rescue line, offering the country up to $40 billion  to meet its debt obligations.
articles.lead_paragraph: BRUSSELS — European leaders provided a long-awaited financial rescue line to Greece on Sunday, offering the country up to $40 billion in aid to meet its giant debt obligations.
articles.byline: By Stephen Castle and Jack Ewing

articles.headline: Leaders Gather for Nuclear Talks as New Threat Is Seen
articles.snippet: A nuclear arms race may be escalating in South Asia, but the problem is not set to be discussed when President Obama’s nuclear security summit meeting opens Monday in Washington.
articles.abstract: A nuclear arms race may be escalating in South Asia, but the problem is not set to be discussed when President Obama’s nuclear security summit meeting opens Monday in Washington.
articles.lead_paragraph: WASHINGTON — Three months ago, American intelligence officials examining satellite photographs of Pakistani nuclear facilities saw the first wisps of steam from the cooling towers of a new nuclear reactor. It was one of three plants being constructed to make fuel for a second generation of nuclear arms.
articles.byline: By David E. Sanger and William J. Broad

articles.headline: U.S. Faults Regulators Over a Bank
articles.snippet: The overseers of Washington Mutual could not agree to declare it unsound until a week before it was seized and sold, a federal investigation found.
articles.abstract: The overseers of Washington Mutual could not agree to declare it unsound until a week before it was seized and sold, a federal investigation found.
articles.lead_paragraph: WASHINGTON — Regulators failed for years to properly supervise the giant savings and loan Washington Mutual, even as the company wobbled under the weight of risky subprime mortgages, a federal investigation has concluded.

articles.headline: News Sites Rethink Anonymous Online Comments
articles.snippet: Sites that once embraced anonymous comments are revising their policies to hold users more accountable.
articles.abstract: Sites that once embraced anonymous comments are revising their policies to hold users more accountable.
articles.lead_paragraph: From the start, Internet users have taken for granted that the territory was both a free-for-all and a digital disguise, allowing them to revel in their power to address the world while keeping their identities concealed.

articles.headline: Civilians Killed as U.S. Troops Fire on Afghan Bus
articles.snippet: An attack that killed as many as five people infuriated leaders in Kandahar before an important offensive.
articles.abstract: An attack that killed as many as five people infuriated leaders in Kandahar before an important offensive.
articles.lead_paragraph: KABUL, Afghanistan — American troops raked a large passenger bus with gunfire near Kandahar on Monday morning, killing and wounding civilians, and igniting angry anti-American demonstrations in a city where winning over Afghan support is pivotal to the war effort.
articles.byline: By Richard A. Oppel Jr. and Taimoor Shah

articles.headline: Dow Finishes Above 11,000
articles.snippet: The highest close since September 2008 was the latest marker in a rally that has brought Wall Street back from the brink.
articles.abstract: The highest close since September 2008 was the latest marker in a rally that has brought Wall Street back from the brink.
articles.lead_paragraph: A few little points was all it took.
